audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a windy ambient sound, suggesting an outdoor environment. A single, male speaker then describes a "stump with metal handle hidden box" and his intrigue towards it because of its "remote, isolated and extremely difficult" location, speaking in a curious tone. The ambient sound of wind persists underneath the speech. He notes a possible road nearby, mentioning that he checked with Google Earth. After a short breath, the speaker continues talking, mentioning what happens when we look at this. Finally, the clip ends with the introduction of music. The style is electronic, ambient, and mysterious, featuring synthesizer sounds.

The clip begins with a male speaker using a matter-of-fact tone and says "It's a terrorist attraction" before clicking on something. Following that click, he notes that it has "a five star review," and continues in a similarly neutral tone. He then references a review made "a day ago" by Scott Miller which simply says "Scott was here."

The audio clip starts with speech. A single male speaker expresses suspicion that a tourist attraction is new, but declares a need to visit it to "leave a review," stating it's not for the adventure but to tell people "I have been there." The tone shifts dramatically to sound effects. A low-frequency rumble occurs, suggesting nearby movement or mechanical operations.

The clip begins with a male speaker commenting on Google Road, stating that it's "not even close" but "in some places" it finds the road, albeit a "very faint" one. He then identifies it as "a road" in New Mexico and that one can "find portions of the road". The male speaker seems to be giving a casual commentary. After this spoken portion, the clip transitions to instrumental music.

The audio begins with a male speaker describing how there are roads across a ravine, but it is difficult to get across. He indicates that there is no road to the place they want to go, and then he expresses his desire to go to a different location, stating that he is "called to go there."

The clip starts with a male voice speaking. He describes being told by "the Lord" to travel a road to its end, even if he loses his "ass" along the way, and expresses his intention to follow this instruction. The speaker sounds confident as he states his plan. The man further notes that he believes it will be easy to get to a specific location where "Forest Road 106" meets a "very faint road."

The clip begins with someone stating that they will have to bring a chainsaw and chains to drag stuff out of the road so they can get through there. They contemplate aloud whether they would be crazy not to go, and then affirm that every sane person should go. The scene transitions to a vehicle interior with sounds of movement. The speaker makes noises of physical exertion and then announces something about power stations. They also mention something about silver tea service stuff. They say they are going camping, and that the dog pup gets to go with them. They mention getting rid of something, and close by saying they are looking forward to it.

A male speaker expresses anticipation for something with "Lola is looking forward to it." He outlines plans to set up a base camp and then inspect forest property, potentially for purchase, ending with "Wouldn't that be cool?" The only background sound appears to be his breathing, which suggests he may be active.

The audio clip starts with someone stating they are at "9050 feet above mean sea level." followed by a reference to "star and space," and then describes a 35-watt battery charger for a 100-amp battery. The speaker then says "More power," suggesting a desire for increased energy capabilities.

The audio clip begins with the sound of humming. This fades as a male speaker begins talking about checking out a property from base camp and investigating a "mysterious stump" with a handle and a hidden box. He expresses hope to go in a few days and notes that spring is here, though the cottonwood trees don't have leaves yet. He mentions bringing firewood but acknowledges the risk of starting fires, and suggests bringing kindling. He states that he is looking forward to it. Throughout the speech there are sounds of panting.

The clip begins with a male speaker declaring this is a "low technology trip" and he "won't have computer nor will I have internet." He expresses excitement to go. He wonders how Lola got so fat, saying it just "snuck up on us," and how he turned around and "oh shit, Lola's fat."
